There are examples around the world of the implementation and scale up of successful Community-based Management of Acute Malnutrition Model (CMAM) programmes. On this page we explore some of the barriers programmes have faced and the innovative ideas that are emerging in the field.

paragraphs.text: We’ve worked with implementers in various contexts to compile answers to frequently asked questions on implementing CMAM programmes.
Explore potential solutions to the barriers your programme is facing here.

The 'Family MUAC' approach trains mothers and caregivers to identify early signs of malnutrition in their children using a simple to use Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) tape. By moving this task to mothers and caregivers, who are able to use MUAC as effectively as community health workers (CHWs), acute malnutrition is detected earlier and potential life-threatening complications are reduced. Mothers are empowered to manage their children's health and CHWs have more time to carry out other tasks.
Visit the Family MUAC Community of Practice for resources, case studies, and frequently asked questions.

Simplified approaches can refer to a range of modifications to the standard Community-based Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) approach. These modifications are designed to improve the coverage and costs of care for children with uncomplicated wasting or as a short-term solution in emergency contexts. While this can include broader simplifications, this community of practice focuses on a core package of options for simplifying approaches to treat acute malnutrition as one continuum across the whole severity of acute malnutrition (both moderate and severe).
Visit the Community of Practice on Simplified Approaches to Acute Malnutrition Treatment for curated key resources and links to further information.

Treatment Coverage is defined as the proportion of people eligible for a service in comparison with the number of people who actually receive that service. For Community-based Management of Acute Malnutrition (CMAM) programmes, effectiveness (i.e. cure rate) and treatment coverage are strongly linked. When combined, they indicate the extent to which a CMAM programme is meeting the needs of the target population. Therefore, investigating coverage (and the factors which influence it) is essential to improving the overall performance of the programme and to understanding how CMAM is perceived by the population.
Visit the Coverage Community of Practice for resources, case studies, and frequently asked questions.

To date, less than a quarter of children affected by wasting receive treatment and evidence on cost-effective ways to scale-up wasting treatment is urgently needed. Integration of wasting treatment into national primary healthcare services, treatment at the community level by community health workers as well as new 'simplified approaches' all have the potential to increase the coverage of services. This page provides a one-stop-shop for information regarding costing and cost-effectiveness of child wasting treatment programmes.
Visit the Community of Practice on cost-effectiveness for available evidence, tools and guidance, links to a webinar series and more..

Between 2015 and 2020, The State of Acute Malnutrition was supported by theNo Wasted LivesCoalition, an interagency effort between Action Against Hunger, the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation, the European Commission Directorate-General for Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection (ECHO), the innocent foundation, the International Rescue Committee (IRC), UNICEF, and World Food Programme (WFP). The CMAM 2.0: Reinventing Community Management of Acute Malnutrition grant supported by the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation that financed the No Wasted Lives initiative, is now closed.
